comments:
General principles of biology focusing on structure and function of animals, with emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, evolution, ecology, and the diversity of adaptations. Lab fee $150.

	Students generally regarded the content of this course as interesting. The large volume of material covered was frequently noted by students. Additionally, students found the format of three professors teaching the course to be “confusing,” “difficult,” and lacking in organization. The lectures were thought by many students to be unnecessary given these circumstances.

	Professor Petraitis was one of three professors for this course. Students predominantly considered the professors as a group to be “ok,” often commenting on the professors’ reading from the slides verbatim and their lack of accessibility. However, students found Professor Petraitis to be the “most engaging” and the “lecturer that stimulated…interest.”

       Students found the course to be very difficult. The volume of material and the amount of work required outside of class were frequently noted by students. The tests were widely considered to be exceedingly difficult, regarded as “difficult to study for” and “tricky for no good reason.” Students recommended the class to majors and pre-meds and not to those looking to take the class as a general requirement or elective. BIOL 102 is the companion course to BIOL 101, and may be taken before or after BIOL 101.

This courses studies general principles of biology focusing on structure and function of animals, with emphasis on the principles of physiology, development, evolution, ecology, and the diversity of adaptations. BIOL 102 is the companion course to BIOL 101 and may be taken before or after BIOL 101.  There is a Lab fee of $150.

	Students felt the course was “interesting,” but several voiced concerns over the material being covered.  One student felt, “there was… a substantial amount of time spent on topics of little interest, like ecology… while the main area of interest (anatomy and physiology) was saved until the end of the course.”  Students also felt they were forced to “blindly memorize the most esoteric information” in order to succeed.  

	Students praised Professor Sanders for being “hilarious,” though with a sense of humor that “rubs some people the wrong way.” He was described as having “a real passion for the subject matter.”  Additionally, students felt “he thoughtfully presents the required material.”  One student described him as “one of my favorite teachers all time.”  Some students were not happy with his exams, as they “were a reflection of how well you could memorize facts” and often do not “reflect the distribution of material taught in lecture.”  Though some thought his lectures were boring, overall, students felt Professor Sanders was engaging and clear and made learning the material fun.

	Students highly recommended this course for majors, but did not recommend it for non-majors.  BIOL 101 is not a prerequisite for this course, but rather is a companion course as part of a yearlong sequence.
